lens.book: The Innovator's Dilemma — Ch 5-7 (Managing Disruptive Technological Change)
lens.auditor_role: Coherence Auditor — checking new reverse-benchmark elements against existing element library
lens.core_question: Do the new reverse-benchmark elements reinforce, contradict, or extend what is already in the library?

reinforcements.new_element_name: Week-Pattern Search Filter with Day-of-Week Selector, Duration Slider, and Schedule-Flexibility Toggle
library_elements_reinforced: guest-looks-006: Schedule Compatibility Indicator: Day-of-Week Pattern as First Visual Signal on Listing Cards
guest-communicates-006: Schedule-First Listing Cards: Lead with Pattern Fit, Not Property Features
guest-works-006: Surface Real-Time Availability Inside the Guest's Decision Flow
rb-ui-005: Stay Purpose Selector
reinforcements.analysis: The design-stack (inside-out process) independently identified schedule as the primary visual signal on listing cards (guest-looks-006) and schedule-first listing layout (guest-communicates-006). The reverse-benchmark (outside-in process) arrived at the same conclusion from the opposite direction: Zillow's structural inability to add schedule-based search means the search filter itself is the highest-priority UI element. Both processes agree that day-of-week pattern must be the FIRST visual signal, not a secondary filter. The rb-ui-005 Stay Purpose Selector from the Airbnb/Cialdini run also converges on the same principle: the platform must ask about the user's situation before showing listings. This three-way convergence — design-stack, Zillow reverse-benchmark, and Airbnb reverse-benchmark — is the strongest possible signal.
reinforcements.why_this_matters: When inside-out user research (Kahneman lens on host/guest calls) and outside-in competitor analysis (Christensen lens on Zillow's structural disabilities) independently identify the same need, the signal is not theoretical — it is empirically convergent. Schedule-native search is validated from every analytical angle available.

library_elements_reinforced: works-001: System 1 Trust Gate at Every Phase Transition
works-004: Bridge Human Trust to Digital Trust Through Continuity Priming
communicates-003: Trust Credential Stack: Process Before Promise, Verification Before Claim
looks-004: Green Trust Badges: Accent Color Reserved Exclusively for Verified and Guaranteed Elements
feels-001: Cognitive Ease as the Foundation of Trust: The First 2 Seconds Set Everything
rb-ui-001: Mutual Pledge Card
rb-ui-006: Commitment Reassurance Badge
reinforcements.analysis: The element library's trust architecture — built from Kahneman's System 1/System 2 framework applied to host calls — prescribes layered trust signals at every phase transition (works-001), human-to-digital trust bridging (works-004), and a trust credential stack showing process before promise (communicates-003). The Ghost Roommate Trust Profile Card from the Zillow/Christensen reverse-benchmark arrives at the same layered structure from a completely different analytical angle: Zillow's structural inability to show human identity on listings means the trust profile card is the element that exploits Zillow's deepest disability. The Airbnb/Cialdini run produced the Mutual Pledge Card (rb-ui-001) and Commitment Reassurance Badge (rb-ui-006) — both addressing trust at the commitment moment. All three processes converge: trust must be progressive, layered, and bilateral.
reinforcements.why_this_matters: Trust is now validated as the emotional centerpiece of the platform from three independent lenses: cognitive psychology (Kahneman), disruptive innovation theory (Christensen), and persuasion psychology (Cialdini). Each lens identifies different trust dimensions (System 1 assessment, structural competitor disability, commitment consistency), but they all demand the same architectural response: visible, layered, bilateral trust signals.

library_elements_reinforced: guest-works-001: Self-Service Date Changes at Conversational Speed
guest-behaves-002: Date Change Request as a Three-Tap Contextual Flow
guest-works-002: Make Replace, Add, and Remove Financially Legible at the Moment of Choice
guest-communicates-003: Inline Financial Consequence for Every Date Change Option
guest-looks-003: Date Change Options as Visually Distinct Financial Cards
works-003: Match the Platform's Cognitive Speed to the Phone Call's Conversational Speed
reinforcements.analysis: This is the strongest reinforcement in the entire audit. The design-stack already produced six directly relevant elements for date changes. The reverse-benchmark independently produced an element that is nearly identical in specification: three-tap flow, financial impact preview, host notification. The inside-out process (Kahneman lens on Nneka's frustration with manual rescheduling) and the outside-in process (Christensen lens on Zillow's complete absence of post-lease tools) converge on the exact same interaction pattern. The design-stack defined the need; the reverse-benchmark confirms that NO competitor will fill it.
reinforcements.why_this_matters: When the design-stack produces a detailed interaction specification (three-tap, financial preview, host notification) and the reverse-benchmark independently produces the same specification from competitor gap analysis, the element should be treated as design-complete and ready for engineering prioritization.

library_elements_reinforced: communicates-004: Pre-Packaged Proposal: Present Decisions as Confirmations, Not Constructions
behaves-003: Confirm-Not-Construct: Proposals Respond to a Tap, Not a Form
guest-communicates-005: Proposal Progress Pipeline: Show the Guest Where They Are, What Happens Next, and Who Acts
guest-looks-007: Proposal Pipeline as Action-Assigned Progress Bar
guest-behaves-004: Proposal Pipeline as Anxiety-Resolving Status Stream
reinforcements.analysis: The design-stack's proposal elements (communicates-004, behaves-003) emphasize SIMPLIFICATION: proposals should feel like confirmations, not constructions. The reverse-benchmark's Bilateral Proposal Builder emphasizes NEGOTIATION: both parties must have equal tools to shape terms. These are convergent on the goal (replace one-directional applications) but diverge on the mechanism (pre-packaged vs. bilateral). This is a productive tension, not a contradiction — see contradictions section for resolution.
reinforcements.why_this_matters: The proposal flow is the fulcrum of the entire platform. Both processes agree it must replace one-directional applications, but they approach the UX from different angles. The resolution requires combining both insights: the initial proposal should be pre-packaged (design-stack), but the counter-proposal flow should be bilateral (reverse-benchmark).

library_elements_reinforced: rb-ui-005: Stay Purpose Selector
feels-008: The Human Thread: The Host Should Always Feel One Step from a Real Person
communicates-001: Anchor-Then-Advance: Open Every Screen with What the Host Already Knows
reinforcements.analysis: The Airbnb/Cialdini reverse-benchmark produced the Stay Purpose Selector (rb-ui-005), which asks guests to declare their situation at the top of search. The Zillow/Christensen reverse-benchmark independently produced the Situation-Based Discovery Prompt (elem-007), which replaces Buy/Rent/Sell navigation with situation-based cards. Both reverse-benchmark lenses — from completely different books and competitors — converge on the same principle: the platform must ask 'Who are you?' before 'What are you looking for?' The design-stack's Anchor-Then-Advance (communicates-001) applies the same logic at the screen level. The convergence across three processes is a strong signal.
reinforcements.why_this_matters: Discovery-as-situation-recognition is now validated from three angles: Cialdini's commitment theory (declaring preferences drives action), Christensen's disruption theory (Zillow's category-based navigation excludes non-standard users), and Kahneman's anchoring theory (recognition before instruction). The element should be prioritized as the first touchpoint of the platform.

contradictions.new_element_name: Bilateral Proposal Builder with Structured Term Negotiation
library_elements_in_tension: communicates-004: Pre-Packaged Proposal: Present Decisions as Confirmations, Not Constructions
behaves-003: Confirm-Not-Construct: Proposals Respond to a Tap, Not a Form
contradictions.analysis: The design-stack's Kahneman-derived insight: a depleted user arriving at the proposal step needs LESS cognitive load, not more. Proposals should be pre-packaged — the platform assembles the proposal from prior inputs, and the guest confirms with a tap. The reverse-benchmark's Christensen-derived insight: mid-term shared housing inherently requires BILATERAL negotiation because every arrangement is custom. Chantel explicitly warns against making it seem like the guest controls everything. These are genuinely in tension: simplification (design-stack) vs. empowerment (reverse-benchmark).
contradictions.resolution: The resolution is SEQUENTIAL, not either/or. The initial proposal follows the design-stack pattern: pre-packaged, confirm-not-construct, minimal cognitive load. The guest sees a pre-assembled proposal based on their search filters and taps to submit. If the host counters, the COUNTER-PROPOSAL flow follows the reverse-benchmark pattern: bilateral, structured, with side-by-side comparison and real-time price translation. This means the proposal flow has two modes: (1) Simple-path: pre-packaged proposal, single tap, no negotiation needed. (2) Negotiation-path: bilateral builder activates only when host counters or guest wants custom terms. The design-stack protects the depleted user's default path. The reverse-benchmark protects the empowered user's negotiation path. Both are preserved.
contradictions.action_required: Update communicates-004 and behaves-003 to specify that confirm-not-construct is the DEFAULT path, with an explicit escape hatch to the Bilateral Proposal Builder when terms need negotiation. Add a new element or annotation: 'Negotiation Mode activates on counter-proposal, not on initial submission.'

library_elements_in_tension: looks-004: Green Trust Badges: Accent Color Reserved Exclusively for Verified and Guaranteed Elements
contradictions.analysis: The existing element library reserves the accent color (#2d5a3d green) exclusively for trust badges. The new Ghost Roommate Trust Profile Card uses purple (secondary-purple, rgb(109, 49, 194)) for verification badges. The reverse-benchmark's entire visual system uses purple as the trust color, not green. This is a direct token conflict: the design-stack says trust = green, the reverse-benchmark says trust = purple.
contradictions.resolution: The design-stack's token system (tokens.json) uses #2d5a3d as 'accent' and reserves it for verified/guaranteed elements. This is the canonical token. The reverse-benchmark elements should be re-skinned to use the token system's green accent for verification badges, while purple can remain the brand/interaction color. Verification = green (trust). Interaction = purple (brand). This preserves both the design-stack's trust-signaling system and the reverse-benchmark's brand identity. See token_compliance section for specifics.
contradictions.action_required: Re-skin elem-002's badge system: replace purple verification badges with green (#2d5a3d) verification badges per looks-004 and tokens.json. Purple remains for interactive elements (buttons, borders, hover states) but NOT for trust verification signals.

extensions.new_element_name: Cleaning Handoff Checklist with Photo Verification, Turnover Timeline, and Shared-Space Status Dashboard
extensions.library_gap_filled: The element library has ZERO elements addressing cleaning coordination, turnover management, or inventory tracking. This is a genuine gap — the design-stack process did not surface cleaning anxiety because the Kahneman lens focused on cognitive processing patterns rather than operational logistics. The reverse-benchmark's Christensen lens surfaced it through Layer 2's new discovery (new-002: Cleaning Coordination Anxiety), which found that Frederick nearly abandoned shared housing entirely because the cleaning burden seemed 'like I'm moving every single week.'
extensions.why_the_library_missed_it: The design-stack's Kahneman lens analyzes HOW users think (System 1/System 2 processing, ego depletion, associative coherence). Cleaning coordination is an OPERATIONAL concern, not a cognitive one — it emerged from transcript evidence about logistics, not about mental processing. This is a healthy blind spot: the design-stack is strong on cognitive architecture, the reverse-benchmark is strong on operational gaps. The combination covers territory neither could reach alone.
extensions.integration_recommendation: Add elem-005 to the element library as a new element in the guest-works or guest-behaves category. It should be cross-referenced with guest-works-003 (Stays Manager as System 1 Dashboard) because the cleaning handoff checklist should live INSIDE the Stays Manager, not as a separate tool. The turnover timeline extends the Stays Manager's weekly view to include cleaning status between guest transitions.

extensions.new_element_name: Multi-Arrangement Reputation Card with Dimensional Scores, Longitudinal Timeline, and Compatibility Preview
extensions.library_gap_filled: The element library has review timing (guest-communicates-007, guest-behaves-006: Batched Review Prompts at Natural Reflection Points) and a review filter (rb-ui-002: People-Like-You Review Filter) and a forward-commitment bridge (rb-ui-004: Post-Review Forward Commitment Bridge). But it has NO element for accumulated reputation display — how multi-arrangement trust data is shown to prospective matches. The Reputation Card fills this gap by defining the visual system for longitudinal trust accumulation.
extensions.why_the_library_missed_it: The design-stack's Kahneman lens analyzed individual cognitive moments (how does a user process a single screen?), not longitudinal patterns (how does trust accumulate across months of arrangements?). The Cialdini lens in the first reverse-benchmark touched on review psychology but focused on the MOMENT of review (commitment at the point of writing), not the ACCUMULATION of reviews over time. The Christensen lens uniquely surfaced this through the Retention Desert (disappoint-010) and Airbnb Regulatory Cliff (new-001): experienced hosts need portable reputation, and the reputation system can only be designed through operational discovery (Ch 7).
extensions.integration_recommendation: Add elem-006 to the element library. Cross-reference it with guest-communicates-007 (review prompts feed data INTO the reputation card), rb-ui-002 (People-Like-You filter operates ON the reputation data), and rb-ui-004 (forward-commitment bridge triggers AFTER a review is added to the reputation). These four elements form a reputation lifecycle: prompt review -> capture review -> filter reviews -> display accumulated reputation -> bridge to next commitment.

extensions.library_gap_filled: The design-stack's schedule-first elements (guest-looks-006, guest-communicates-006) define the visual pattern for displaying schedule compatibility on listing cards. But they assume KNOWN schedules. The reverse-benchmark's Schedule-Flexibility Toggle ('Exact / Flexible / Approximate') is a NEW interaction pattern that accommodates the Schedule Uncertainty Paradox (new-003) — users who need housing for a schedule they do not yet know. This is an extension of the existing schedule elements into uncertainty territory.
extensions.why_the_library_missed_it: The design-stack's user calls included hosts and guests who had already committed to specific schedules. The reverse-benchmark's cross-referencing of 68 transcripts surfaced Vince ('still waiting on them to make things official on the days') and Steve Zhang ('schedule certainty and schedule uncertainty'). Schedule uncertainty is an attribute that only emerges from broad transcript analysis, not from analyzing individual cognitive processing.
extensions.integration_recommendation: Extend guest-looks-006 (Schedule Compatibility Indicator) to include a flexibility dimension: how the indicator changes when the guest selects 'Flexible' or 'Approximate' schedule matching. The listing card should visually distinguish between exact-match, flexible-match, and approximate-match listings.

extensions.new_element_name: Bilateral Proposal Builder (Min-Max Guardrails and Price Translation specifically)
extensions.library_gap_filled: The design-stack's proposal elements assume one-directional proposals: the guest confirms a pre-packaged proposal. The reverse-benchmark adds two new capabilities that do not exist in the library: (1) Min-max guardrails that hosts set to bound negotiation ranges, and (2) Real-time price translation between nightly and monthly formats (solving the problem surfaced by Steven Mariscal's phone call where he manually translated between $1,200/month and $75/night). These are extensions of the proposal architecture, not replacements.
extensions.why_the_library_missed_it: The design-stack's Kahneman lens optimized for cognitive load reduction (fewer decisions = better). Min-max guardrails and price translation ADD complexity to the proposal flow. The Christensen lens revealed that this complexity is NECESSARY because shared housing arrangements are inherently custom — unlike traditional leases where terms are standardized. The design-stack was right to simplify the default path; the reverse-benchmark is right that an empowered path must exist for non-standard terms.
extensions.integration_recommendation: Add min-max guardrails as a host-side configuration element (visible during listing creation, invisible during guest's default proposal path, activated during counter-proposal negotiation). Add price translation as a universal display pattern: every money display across the platform shows both nightly and monthly equivalents. This extends communicates-002 (Single-Sum Financial Display) rather than contradicting it — the single sum is the nightly rate, with the monthly equivalent as secondary context.

cross_process_insights.title: Schedule-Native Housing: Triple Convergence
cross_process_insights.convergence_evidence: Design-stack produced guest-looks-006 (schedule as first visual signal) from analysis of how System 1 processes listing cards. Zillow reverse-benchmark produced elem-001 (schedule as primary search filter) from analysis of Zillow's structural inability to add schedule-based search. Airbnb reverse-benchmark produced rb-ui-005 (Stay Purpose Selector) from analysis of commitment psychology at the discovery moment. All three independently conclude: schedule must be the first thing the platform asks about and the first thing listings display.
cross_process_insights.combined_insight: Schedule-native housing is the single most validated design principle across ALL analytical lenses. It is validated from the user's cognitive processing (Kahneman: System 1 needs instant schedule legibility), from competitor structural analysis (Christensen: Zillow cannot build it), and from persuasion psychology (Cialdini: declaring schedule commitment drives action). No other design principle has triple convergence.
cross_process_insights.action: Elevate schedule-native housing to the top of the engineering roadmap. Treat it as the foundational architectural decision, not a feature.

cross_process_insights.title: Trust as Progressive Choreography: Triple Convergence
cross_process_insights.convergence_evidence: Design-stack produced works-001 (System 1 trust gate at every transition) and communicates-003 (trust credential stack). Zillow reverse-benchmark produced elem-002 (Ghost Roommate Trust Profile Card) from analysis of Zillow's dehumanized listings. Airbnb reverse-benchmark produced rb-ui-001 (Mutual Pledge Card) and rb-ui-006 (Commitment Reassurance Badge) from commitment-consistency psychology. All three independently design PROGRESSIVE trust: trust that builds across phases, not a single trust checkpoint.
cross_process_insights.combined_insight: Trust in shared housing cannot be a single verification step. It must be a choreography that accumulates across the journey: cognitive ease at first impression (Kahneman), verified identity on the profile card (Christensen gap), mutual pledge at commitment (Cialdini), and ongoing reputation across arrangements (Christensen long-term moat). The three lenses together define the trust stack more completely than any single lens could.
cross_process_insights.action: Map the trust choreography across the full journey, assigning specific trust signals to specific phase transitions. Each trust element should cite which lens(es) validated its placement.

cross_process_insights.title: Post-Transaction Platform as Core Product: Double Convergence
cross_process_insights.convergence_evidence: The design-stack produced 7 elements for the Stays Manager (guest-works-001, guest-works-003, guest-works-004, guest-behaves-002, guest-communicates-001, guest-communicates-003, guest-looks-003). The Zillow reverse-benchmark produced elem-004 (Date Swap Card) and elem-005 (Cleaning Handoff Checklist) from analysis of Zillow's complete absence in active-stay management. Both processes converge on: the platform's core product is the LIVING experience, not the SEARCH experience.
cross_process_insights.combined_insight: The design-stack defined the cognitive architecture of post-transaction tools (how the Stays Manager should process information for depleted users). The reverse-benchmark defined the operational features those tools must include (date swaps, cleaning coordination, payment adjustment). Together, they produce a complete specification: the Stays Manager is a System 1 weekly dashboard (design-stack) that includes date swaps, cleaning verification, and financial legibility (reverse-benchmark). Neither process alone would have produced the full picture.
cross_process_insights.action: Treat the Stays Manager as the platform's flagship product surface — the screen users visit most frequently, with the most operational features. Prioritize elem-004 and elem-005 integration into the guest-works-003 Stays Manager architecture.

cross_process_insights.title: Cleaning Coordination as Category-Level Risk: Single-Source Discovery
cross_process_insights.convergence_evidence: The Cleaning Coordination Anxiety (Layer 2, new-002) was discovered exclusively through the reverse-benchmark's broad transcript cross-referencing. The design-stack did not surface cleaning as a concern because its Kahneman lens focused on cognitive processing rather than operational logistics. Frederick's statement — 'it might be a little too stressful' — is a category-level threat: cleaning anxiety can kill the entire shared housing concept.
cross_process_insights.combined_insight: This is a valuable single-source discovery that the design-stack should incorporate. The design-stack's blind spot (operational logistics) was covered by the reverse-benchmark's broad transcript analysis. However, because this is single-source with no design-stack convergence, it should be treated as HIGH PRIORITY but with MODERATE CONFIDENCE — it needs validation through the next design-stack run to achieve gold status.
cross_process_insights.action: Include cleaning coordination in the next design-stack run as a first-class topic for host and guest analysis. Apply the Kahneman lens specifically to cleaning anxiety: what System 1 signals indicate the space is clean? What depletion effects occur from weekly cleaning responsibility?

cross_process_insights.title: Reputation System as Long-Term Moat: Emerging Convergence
cross_process_insights.convergence_evidence: The Zillow reverse-benchmark produced elem-006 (Multi-Arrangement Reputation Card) and opp-005 (Accumulated Housing Identity) from Christensen's agnostic marketing principle: the review system must be discovered through operation. The Airbnb reverse-benchmark produced rb-ui-002 (People-Like-You Review Filter) and rb-ui-004 (Post-Review Forward Commitment Bridge) from Cialdini's social proof and commitment principles. Both reverse-benchmarks converge on: reputation must be multi-dimensional, longitudinal, and actively leveraged for retention.
cross_process_insights.combined_insight: The reputation system is validated from two reverse-benchmark lenses but lacks design-stack convergence. The design-stack has review timing elements (guest-communicates-007: Batched Review Prompts) but no reputation accumulation architecture. The Christensen lens provides the WHAT (multi-dimensional, longitudinal scores) and the Cialdini lens provides the HOW (similarity-filtered, commitment-bridging). The Kahneman lens should provide the WHY (how does System 1 process reputation information?) in a future design-stack run.
cross_process_insights.action: Commission a design-stack run analyzing how users cognitively process reputation signals: what makes a 4.9 Schedule Reliability score trustworthy? How does System 1 evaluate a longitudinal timeline of past arrangements? This would promote reputation from silver to gold.

token_compliance.summary: The 7 new elements from Layer 4 use a purple-centric design system (--primary-purple: #31135D, --secondary-purple: rgb(109,49,194), --chat-purple: rgb(75,71,206)) that conflicts with the established token system in tokens.json. The token system uses warm earth tones (bg: #f6f4f0, ink: #1a1714, accent: #2d5a3d green). The reverse-benchmark elements introduce a completely separate visual vocabulary. This must be reconciled before any element enters production.

specific_violations.remediation: Replace #f9fafb with tokens.json bg (#f6f4f0). The warm undertone is intentional — it creates the 'warm surface continuity' that looks-001 prescribes.

specific_violations.element_value: text-dark: #1a1a1a (cool black), text-gray: #6b7280 (cool gray), text-light-gray: #9ca3af (cool gray)
specific_violations.remediation: Replace text colors with tokens.json ink hierarchy. The warm ink tones support the design-stack's associative warmth principle (feels-005).

specific_violations.token_value: accent: #2d5a3d (green, reserved for trust/verification per looks-004)
specific_violations.element_value: secondary-purple: rgb(109,49,194) used for BOTH brand interaction AND trust verification badges
specific_violations.remediation: Split the purple usage: (1) Brand/interaction purple can remain as a secondary brand color alongside the token system (buttons, hover states, borders). (2) Trust verification badges MUST use accent green (#2d5a3d) per looks-004. This separation preserves the learned trust signal that the design-stack established: green = verified/guaranteed. Mixing purple into trust signals would fragment this learned association.

specific_violations.token_value: serif: Instrument Serif, sans: Outfit, mono: IBM Plex Mono
specific_violations.element_value: Inter and DM Sans throughout all elements
specific_violations.remediation: Replace Inter with Outfit (the token system's sans-serif). Replace DM Sans with Outfit at lighter weights for secondary text. Instrument Serif should be used for recognition-layer headlines per the Typographic Trust Triad (looks-002). This is a significant re-skin but essential for visual cohesion across the platform.
Replace border and shadow values with tokens.json equivalents. The warm undertone in borders and shadows contributes to the overall warmth the design-stack prescribes.

specific_violations.token_value: xs:4px, sm:8px, md:16px, lg:24px, xl:40px, xxl:60px
specific_violations.element_value: Arbitrary pixel values (24px padding, 16px margins, 20px padding, 12px gaps)
specific_violations.remediation: Map element spacing to token scale: 24px = lg, 16px = md, 8px = sm. Most values already map cleanly. Verify 20px values — they fall between md(16) and lg(24) and should be rounded to one or the other.
Map 12px to lg(16px) or md(10px) depending on element size. Map pill buttons to full(9999px). Map 8px to sm(6px) or md(10px).

token_compliance.recommended_process: Create a token-mapping stylesheet that translates reverse-benchmark CSS variables to tokens.json values. Apply this stylesheet to all 7 elements before they enter the library. The interaction patterns and information architecture are sound — only the visual surface needs remediation.

coverage_map.description: Shows which design process contributed elements to each journey phase. DS = Design-Stack (Kahneman lens, inside-out). RB-Z = Reverse-Benchmark/Zillow (Christensen lens, outside-in). RB-A = Reverse-Benchmark/Airbnb (Cialdini lens, outside-in).

discovery.gap_notes: Well-covered from all three processes. The Christensen lens adds the structural argument (Zillow's 4-tab navigation cannot accommodate non-standard users). The Cialdini lens adds the commitment argument (declaring your situation drives action). The Kahneman lens adds the cognitive argument (anchor before advancing).

RB_A_elements: rb-ui-005: Stay Purpose Selector (extends into search)
search.gap_notes: Strong coverage. The reverse-benchmark adds the SEARCH FILTER component that the design-stack's listing-card elements implicitly require but did not explicitly specify. The Schedule-Flexibility Toggle is a unique reverse-benchmark contribution addressing schedule uncertainty.

RB_Z_elements: elem-002: Ghost Roommate Trust Profile Card
listing_evaluation.gap_notes: The design-stack provides the cognitive architecture for how listing evaluation should FEEL. The Zillow reverse-benchmark provides the specific trust profile card that Zillow cannot offer. The Airbnb reverse-benchmark provides the review filter that helps evaluation be RELEVANT. Strong complementary coverage.

DS_elements: guest-behaves-004: Proposal Pipeline as Anxiety-Resolving Status Stream
proposal_creation.gap_notes: Productive tension between design-stack (simplify) and reverse-benchmark (empower). Resolution: simple path as default, bilateral builder as negotiation mode. See contradictions section.

negotiation.gap_notes: SIGNIFICANT GAP: The design-stack has NO elements for the negotiation phase. This is because the Kahneman lens analyzed the HOST journey (where negotiation is handled by Bryant on the phone) rather than the guest's self-service negotiation experience. The reverse-benchmark fills this gap with the Bilateral Proposal Builder and the Mutual Pledge Card. RECOMMENDATION: Add negotiation as a first-class phase in the next design-stack run.

DS_elements: works-005: Engineer the Host-as-Advisor Moment to Lock Commitment
acceptance.gap_notes: Design-stack covers the host's commitment psychology. Airbnb reverse-benchmark covers the mutual commitment moment. Zillow reverse-benchmark does not address acceptance specifically. Adequate coverage.

DS_elements: guest-works-003: Stays Manager as System 1 Dashboard
guest-looks-003: Date Change Options as Visual Cards
active_lease_stay_management.gap_notes: The design-stack has the DEEPEST coverage here (7 elements). The reverse-benchmark confirms and extends with the Date Swap Card (near-identical to design-stack) and adds the Cleaning Handoff Checklist (new territory). The Airbnb/Cialdini reverse-benchmark does not cover active stays. RECOMMENDATION: Add active-stay psychology to the next Cialdini-lens analysis — how does commitment psychology operate during a 16-week stay?

DS_elements: guest-behaves-005: Payment Schedule as Passive Confidence
retention_post_stay.gap_notes: Good coverage across all three processes. The design-stack defines WHEN to prompt reviews. The Zillow reverse-benchmark defines HOW to display accumulated reputation. The Airbnb reverse-benchmark defines HOW to filter and leverage reviews for retention. Together, they form a complete review/reputation lifecycle.

coverage_map.overall_assessment: Of 8 journey phases audited, 5 have triple coverage (all three processes contributing), 2 have double coverage, and 1 (negotiation) has reverse-benchmark-only coverage. The negotiation gap in the design-stack is the most significant finding: it should be addressed in the next design-stack run. The overall coverage is strong, with the reverse-benchmark process successfully filling operational and competitive gaps that the design-stack's cognitive lens could not reach.

next_run_recommendations.recommendation: Run a design-stack analysis of the NEGOTIATION phase
next_run_recommendations.rationale: The coverage map reveals negotiation as the only phase with zero design-stack coverage. The reverse-benchmark produced the Bilateral Proposal Builder, but it lacks Kahneman-lens analysis of how depleted users process counter-proposals, how System 1 evaluates negotiation fairness, and what cognitive biases affect term modification decisions. A Kahneman-lens analysis of negotiation transcripts (Chantel's detailed negotiation feedback, Steven Mariscal's real-time price translation) would promote negotiation coverage from silver to gold.

next_run_recommendations.recommendation: Apply Kahneman lens to CLEANING COORDINATION anxiety
next_run_recommendations.rationale: The Cleaning Handoff Checklist (elem-005) is currently a single-source discovery from the reverse-benchmark. To achieve gold-level confidence, the design-stack should analyze cleaning anxiety through the Kahneman lens: What System 1 signals indicate cleanliness? What depletion effects occur from weekly cleaning responsibility? How does photo verification affect cognitive ease? Frederick's near-rejection of shared housing ('it might be a little too stressful') is a System 2 override of a System 1 threat assessment — exactly the kind of dynamic the Kahneman lens is built to analyze.

next_run_recommendations.recommendation: Run a reverse-benchmark against Furnished Finder using a different book lens
next_run_recommendations.rationale: Zillow is structurally irrelevant to the mid-term housing segment (zero mentions in 68 transcripts). Furnished Finder, however, IS mentioned by users (Dana found it there) and IS operating in the mid-term space. A reverse-benchmark against Furnished Finder would surface OPERATIONAL disappointments (not structural ones) — what does Furnished Finder do poorly that Split Lease can do well? Suggested book: 'The Design of Everyday Things' by Don Norman, focusing on affordances and mental models in stay management interfaces.

next_run_recommendations.recommendation: Commission a Kahneman-lens analysis of REPUTATION PROCESSING
next_run_recommendations.rationale: The Reputation Card (elem-006) defines what accumulated trust data LOOKS like, but the design-stack has not analyzed how users PROCESS reputation information. How does System 1 evaluate a 4.9 Schedule Reliability score? Does a longitudinal timeline of past arrangements create associative coherence? At what threshold does reputation data override the need for human trust-building (phone calls, Zoom meetings)? This analysis would complete the reputation system design.

next_run_recommendations.recommendation: Resolve token compliance before adding elements to library
next_run_recommendations.rationale: All 7 new elements use a purple/cool-gray visual system that conflicts with the established warm-tone token system. Creating a token-mapping stylesheet and re-skinning the elements should precede library integration. The interaction patterns and information architecture are validated — only the visual surface needs alignment.

next_run_recommendations.recommendation: Explore a reverse-benchmark against PROPERTY MANAGEMENT SOFTWARE (Buildium, AppFolio)
next_run_recommendations.rationale: The Living Rhythm Manager (opp-004) and Cleaning Handoff Checklist (elem-005) occupy territory between consumer platforms and property management tools. A reverse-benchmark against Buildium or AppFolio might surface operational features that shared housing needs but that are locked inside landlord-facing enterprise software. Suggested book: 'Crossing the Chasm' by Geoffrey Moore, focusing on the pragmatist buyer's adoption requirements.
